THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
1.  Maharashtra is the second largest state of India in terms of population (estimated at 112 
million in 2018) and third largest in terms of land area (308,000 square kilometers [km2]). The 
majority of the state’s population (54.8%) live in rural areas and depend primarily on agriculture 
for  employment  and  income generation.  Rural  connectivity  underpins  rural  development  in 
Maharashtra. Maharashtra has a road network of 303,000 kilometers (km), of which 67% are rural 
roads.1 Roads are the dominant mode of transportation, accounting for more than 80% of 
passenger traffic and 60% of freight traffic. Years of underinvestment have adversely affected the 
condition of roads, especially rural roads. In rural areas, many villages still rely on earthen tracks 
that are unsuitable for motorized traffic and often become impassable during the rainy season. 
Poor  road  infrastructure  exacerbates  poverty  and  constricts  economic  growth,  agricultural 
productivity, and employment. The State Government of Maharashtra recognizes the importance 
of rural connectivity in improving rural livelihoods and alleviating poverty. Accordingly, it has 
initiated two rural road construction and rehabilitation programs, namely the Prime Minister’s 
Rural Road Development Program (PMGSY) and the Chief Minister’s Rural Road Scheme 
(MMGSY)  program.  The  Maharashtra  Rural  Road  Development  Association  (MRRDA)  is 
responsible for implementing the PMGSY and MMGSY schemes. 
2.  The proposed project supports the MMGSY and is aligned with the following impact: 
Quality, reliable, sustainable, safe, and affordable roads that provide equitable access for all 
developed (Vision 2030). The project will have the following outcome: Road transport efficiency 
and road safety in 34 districts of Maharashtra increased.2 The project outputs are: (i) conditions 
and safety of selected rural roads improved and maintained; and (ii) capacity of rural infrastructure 
agency and awareness among road users in the state enhanced. The project is estimated to cost 
$296  million. The government has requested a regular loan of $200 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources to help finance the project. 
  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
3.  The  proposed  transaction  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  complement  the  project  by 
strengthening the capacity of the Maharashtra Rural Road Development Association (MRRDA) in 
managing rural road infrastructure. This will ensure efficient decision making on road design, 
construction, and operation and maintenance. The TA will support measures to ensure the 
sustainability of the assets improved under the MMGSY program.  
B.  Outputs and Activities  
4.  Output: Capacity of rural infrastructure agency and awareness among road users in the 
State enhanced. This output will expose the MRRDA to international practices related to rural 
road design, construction, and operation and maintenance. The output will improve the ability of 
the  MRRDA  to  manage  rural road  networks by  strengthening its  capacity  in: (i) road  asset 
management (including performance-based maintenance); (ii) road safety; (iii) climate-resilient 
design and construction; and (iv) web-based, real-time project monitoring.  
                                                
1  State Government of Maharashtra, Planning Department. 2018. Vision 2030. Mumbai. 
2  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

2     
C.  Cost and Financing 
5.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.0 million which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
ADB Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of staff, office space, and other in-kind contributions. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1.   
6.  The TA proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
7.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants and 
administer the TA. It will be implemented over 24 months and is expected to start in September 
2019 and end in September 2021. The State of Maharashtra, acting through the MRRDA, will be 
the executing agency.  
8.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

9.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.3 The TA will require about 38 person-months of consulting services 
(about 17 person-months international and 21 person-months national) (Table 2). ADB will recruit 
consultants under one package using the quality-and cost-based selection method with a quality–
cost ratio of 90:10. A simplified technical proposal will be used for the selection of a firm. 
Disbursement  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).
